elements.content: Using the Cu(II)-tpbn system, three new compounds[Cu4(tpbn)2­(glutarate)2­(H2O)4]­(ClO4)4·​xH2O (when x = 2, 1; x = 4, 1a), {[Cu2(tpbn)­(diglyconate)­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2·​solvent} n (when no solvent, 2; solvent = CH3OH/​CH3CN, 2a), and [Cu4(tpbn)2­(2,2′-thiodiacetate)2­(H2O)4]­(ClO4)4·​xH2O (when x = 0, 3; x = 4, 3a), where tpbn = N,N′,N″,N‴-tetrakis(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-diaminobutanehave been synthesized from a one-pot self-assembly reaction in a methanol–​water mixture under ambient conditions. Their formation is dependent on the spacer atom in the dicarboxylate linker: molecular rectangles (1/1a and 3/3a) are obtained with spacer atoms CH2 and S, whereas a helical one-dimensional (1D) coordination polymer (2/2a) is obtained with O as the spacer atom in the linker. These are the first molecular rectangles containing the dicarboxylates used in this study. In addition to their characterization by elemental analysis and UV–vis and IR spectroscopy, their solid-state molecular structures are determined by single-crystal X-ray diffractometry. Using electrospray mass spectrometry, their structural integrity in the solution state is confirmed. Water vapor adsorption study of 1–3 corroborates well with their solid-state structures in terms of their affinity toward water: 3 shows a stepwise adsorption with a maximum water vapor intake of 16 water molecules per molecule of 3, having a small hysteresis loop, while 1 shows a continuous adsorption with a maximum water vapor intake of 10.5 water molecules per molecule of 1, having a larger hysteresis loop, and 2 has the least affinity. Similarly, adsorption of CO2 is 3 times more by 1 than 3 at 296 K, and both show selectivity for CO2 over N2. Comparison of their magnetic behavior based on variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements (2–300 K) indicates weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Cu(II) centers in 1 and 3 and a weak ferromagnetic interaction between the Cu(II) centers in 2. This is well correlated to the Cu···Cu distances in these compounds. Each compound showed a characteristic broad isotropic electron paramagnetic resonance signal for distorted square-pyramidal Cu(II) ions at 77 K.

elements.content: The study of coordination polymers (CPs) and their porous congeners has led inorganic chemists to generate a large number of examples providing opportunities to showcase their potential in various applications, including catalysis, magnetochemistry, gas adsorption and storage, gas/vapor separation, molecule recognition, and encapsulation. In developing such compounds, both ancillary ligands and the multiatom organic linkers are important. For our efforts in this field with transition metal ions, we have systematically studied the effect of ancillary ligands as well as the linkers in generating molecular squares/​rectangles and CPs. The number and orientation of open sites on the metal center dictate the formation of the product. In a dimetal subunit (which can be a metal–metal bond or two metal centers connected by a spanning ligand), if the open sites on each metal center are cis to each other, it would result in the formation of a square or rectangles, whereas if the open sites are trans to each other, it would result in the formation of a CP; such CPs could be helical in nature as well (see Figure ). The helicity in CPs is important because it imparts chirality and other geometric features which have fascinated scientists from various branches of chemistry. In particular, the design and synthesis of coordination helical structures with desired functionalities have become important issues in recent years due to various applications in the fields of asymmetric catalysis, chiral chemistry, nonlinear optical materials, template precursors, memory devices, biomimetics, structural biology, specific ion sensors, and molecular reaction vessels.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The study of coordination polymers (CPs) and their porous congeners has led inorganic chemists to generate a large number of examples providing opportunities to showcase their potential in various applications, including catalysis, magnetochemistry, gas adsorption and storage, gas/vapor separation, molecule recognition, and encapsulation. In developing such compounds, both ancillary ligands and the multiatom organic linkers are important. For our efforts in this field with transition metal ions, we have systematically studied the effect of ancillary ligands as well as the linkers in generating molecular squares/rectangles and CPs. The number and orientation of open sites on the metal center dictate the formation of the product. In a dimetal subunit (which can be a metal-metal bond or two metal centers connected by a spanning ligand), if the open sites on each metal center are cis to each other, it would result in the formation of a square or rectangles, whereas if the open sites are trans to each other, it would result in the formation of a CP; such CPs could be helical in nature as well (see Figure ). The helicity in CPs is important because it imparts chirality and other geometric features which have fascinated scientists from various branches of chemistry. In particular, the design and synthesis of coordination helical structures with desired functionalities have become important issues in recent years due to various applications in the fields of asymmetric catalysis, chiral chemistry, nonlinear optical materials, template precursors, memory devices, biomimetics, structural biology, specific ion sensors, and molecular reaction vessels.

elements.content: While a large number of examples of the linear 1D CP are now available in the literature, there are only a limited number of step-style 1D CPs. For the Cu(II)-tpbn system (where tpbn = N,N′,N″,N‴-tetrakis(2-pyridylmethyl)-1,4-di­aminobutane) with a variation of the dicarboxylate linkers within the aliphatic chain, such as the spacer atoms CH2, O, or S, either a molecular rectangle, e.g., [Cu4(tpbn)2­(glutarate)2­(H2O)4]­(ClO4)4·2H2O (1) and [Cu4(tpbn)2­(2,2′-thiodiacetate)2­(H2O)4]­(ClO4)4 (3), or a 1D helical CP, {[Cu2(tpbn)­(diglyconate)­(H2O)2]­(ClO4)2} n (2), is isolated (see Figure for the structures of the ligand and linkers). Furthermore, compound 2, which crystallizes in a chiral space group, maintains its chirality in the solution, as determined by polarimetry. In this contribution, we report their synthesis and structural characterization by elemental analysis, IR and UV–vis spectroscopy, mass spectrometry, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. Also reported are the water vapor adsorption study of 1–3 that corroborates well with their solid-state structures (showing a difference in the affinity toward water vapor) and the carbon dioxide adsorption study for the molecular rectangles. Their magnetic behavior studied through variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements (2–300 K) shows weakly antiferromagnetic (in 1 and 3) and weakly ferromagnetic (in 2) interactions between the Cu(II) centers.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals and solvents used for synthesis were obtained from commercial sources and were used as received, without further purification. All reactions were carried out under aerobic conditions. The tpbn ligand was prepared following a literature procedure.

elements.content:
Caution! In this study metal perchlorates were used without any problem, but special care should be taken to handle such salts, which are dangerous.

Physical Measurements

The 1H NMR spectrum of the tpbn ligand was obtained in CDCl3 solution at 25 °C on a Bruker ARX-400 spectrometer. Chemical shifts are reported relative to the residual solvent signals. Elemental analysis (C, H, N) was carried out using a Mettler CHNS analyzer. IR spectra were measured in the 4000–400 cm–1 range on a Perkin-Elmer Spectrum I spectrometer with samples prepared as KBr pellets. The UV–vis spectra were recorded using 1 mM solution on an Agilent Cary 60 spectrometer. Electrospray ionization (ESI) mass spectrometry was performed using a Thermo Scientific LTQ XL LC-MS instrument for the 50–2000 amu range. Optical rotations were recorded using Anton Paar modular circular polarimeter (MCP 300); measurements were carried out using a glass cell with 50 mm path length. Magnetic susceptibility measurements were carried out using the VSM option of an EC-II PPMS Quantum Design system to obtain χ versus T in the temperature range 2–300 K in an applied magnetic field H = 1 T, and the magnetization M versus magnetic field H at T = 2 K. EPR spectra of 1–3 were recorded at 77 K on a Bruker EMX spectrometer.

elements.content: First, 46.5 mg (0.125 mmol) of Cu(ClO4)2·​6H2O and 28.5 mg (0.0625 mmol) of tpbn were dissolved in 3 mL of methanol. To this was added a clear solution of disodium glutarate (Na2­glutarate), prepared from 8.5 mg (0.0625 mmol) of glutaric acid and 5 mg (0.125 mmol) of sodium hydroxide, and a blue precipitate appeared immediately. The reaction mixture was stirred for another 3 h at room temperature. A blue solid was obtained via filtration, washed with methanol, and vacuum dried. It should be noted that if the amount of glutarate is doubled (0.125 mmol) in this reaction, there is no change in the product formation and yield; the excess carboxylate is wasted in the filtrate. Yield: 44 mg (81.2%). Anal. Calcd for C66H88N12Cu4Cl4O30 (MW 1925.24): C, 41.17; H, 4.51; N, 8.72. Found: C, 40.94; H, 4.34; N, 9.04. Selected FTIR peaks (KBr, cm–1): 3429 (br), 1609 (vs), 1595 (s), 1483 (m), 1375 (s), 1101 (vs), 764 (m), 624 (m). UV–vis (1 mM, acetonitrile): λmax, 637 nm.

elements.content: Crystals of the compounds were transferred from mother liquor to mineral oil for manipulation, selection, and mounting. They were then transferred to a thin glass fiber on a goniometer head, which was then placed under a cold stream of nitrogen gas for slow cooling to the desired temperature in each case. Initial crystal evaluation and data collection were performed on a Kappa APEX II diffractometer equipped with a CCD detector (with the crystal-to-detector distance fixed at 60 mm) and sealed-tube monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The diffractometer was interfaced to a personal computer that controlled the crystal centering, unit cell determination, refinement of the cell parameters, and data collection through the program APEX2. For each sample, three sets of frames of data were collected with 0.30° steps in ω and an exposure time of 10 s within a randomly oriented region of reciprocal space, surveyed to the extent of 1.3 hemispheres to a resolution of 0.85 Å. By using the program SAINT for the integration of the data, reflection profiles were fitted, and values of F 2 and σ(F 2) for each reflection were obtained. Data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The subroutine XPREP was used for the processing of data that included determination of space group, application of an absorption correction (SADABS), merging of data, and generation of files necessary for solution and refinement. The crystal structures were solved and refined using SHELX 97. Several full-matrix least-squares/​difference Fourier cycles were performed, locating the remainder of the non-hydrogen atoms. Occupancy factors of some atoms were adjusted to have reasonable thermal parameters and converged refinement, resulting in the lowest residual factors and optimum goodness of fit. Crystallographic parameters and basic information pertaining to data collection and structure refinement for all compounds are summarized in Table . All figures were drawn using Mercury V 3.0 and OLEX2, and hydrogen-bonding parameters were generated using PLATON. The final positional and thermal parameters of the non-hydrogen atoms for all structures are listed in the CIF files ().

The diffractometer was interfaced to a personal computer that controlled the crystal centering, unit cell determination, refinement of the cell parameters, and data collection through the program APEX2. For each sample, three sets of frames of data were collected with 0.30° steps in ω and an exposure time of 10 s within a randomly oriented region of reciprocal space, surveyed to the extent of 1.3 hemispheres to a resolution of 0.85 Å. By using the program SAINT for the integration of the data, reflection profiles were fitted, and values of F 2 and σ(F 2) for each reflection were obtained. Data were also corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. The subroutine XPREP was used for the processing of data that included determination of space group, application of an absorption correction (SADABS), merging of data, and generation of files necessary for solution and refinement. The crystal structures were solved and refined using SHELX 97. Several full-matrix least-squares/difference Fourier cycles were performed, locating the remainder of the non-hydrogen atoms. Occupancy factors of some atoms were adjusted to have reasonable thermal parameters and converged refinement, resulting in the lowest residual factors and optimum goodness of fit. Crystallographic parameters and basic information pertaining to data collection and structure refinement for all compounds are summarized in Table . All figures were drawn using Mercury V 3.0 and OLEX2, and hydrogen-bonding parameters were generated using PLATON. Powder X-ray Studies

Data were recorded on a Rigaku Ultima IV diffractometer equipped with a 3 kW sealed tube for CuKα X-ray radiation (generator power settings: 40 kV and 40 mA) and a DTex Ultra detector using parallel beam geometry (2.5° primary and secondary solar slits, 0.5° divergence slit, with 10 mm height limit slit). For each sample, a fine powder was packed on a glass sample holder that was placed on the sample rotation stage attachment. The data were collected over an angle range of 5-50° with a scanning speed of 1° per min, with 0.01° step.

elements.content: Data were recorded for pressures in the range of 0–1.2 bar by the volumetric method using a BELSORP-Max instrument. Each solid sample was transferred to pre-weighed analysis tubes, which were capped with transeals and evacuated by heating at a temperature between 110 and 150 °C (based on thermal profile obtained from thermogravimetric analysis) under dynamic vacuum until an outgas rate of less than 2 mTorr min–1 (0.27 Pa min–1) was achieved (ca. 12–24 h). The evacuated analysis tubes containing the degassed sample were then carefully transferred to an electronic balance and weighed again to determine the mass of sample. The tubes were then placed back on the analysis port of the gas adsorption instrument. The outgas rate was again confirmed to be less than 2 mTorr min–1 (0.27 Pa min–1). For all isotherms, warm and cold free-space (dead volume) correction measurements were performed using ultra-high-purity He gas (UHP grade 5.0, 99.999% purity). The change of the pressure was monitored, and the degree of adsorption was determined by the decrease in pressure at the equilibrium state via computer-controlled automatic operations that were set up at the start of each measurement. Oil-free vacuum pumps and oil-free pressure regulators were used for all measurements to prevent contamination of the samples during the evacuation process or of the feed gases during the isotherm measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Vapor/Gas Adsorption Measurements

Data were recorded for pressures in the range of 0-1.2 bar by the volumetric method using a BELSORP-Max instrument. Each solid sample was transferred to pre-weighed analysis tubes, which were capped with transeals and evacuated by heating at a temperature between 110 and 150 °C (based on thermal profile obtained from thermogravimetric analysis) under dynamic vacuum until an outgas rate of less than 2 mTorr min-1 (0.27 Pa min-1) was achieved (ca. 12-24 h). The evacuated analysis tubes containing the degassed sample were then carefully transferred to an electronic balance and weighed again to determine the mass of sample. The tubes were then placed back on the analysis port of the gas adsorption instrument. The outgas rate was again confirmed to be less than 2 mTorr min-1 (0.27 Pa min-1). For all isotherms, warm and cold free-space (dead volume) correction measurements were performed using ultra-high-purity He gas (UHP grade 5.0, 99.999% purity). The change of the pressure was monitored, and the degree of adsorption was determined by the decrease in pressure at the equilibrium state via computer-controlled automatic operations that were set up at the start of each measurement. Oil-free vacuum pumps and oil-free pressure regulators were used for all measurements to prevent contamination of the samples during the evacuation process or of the feed gases during the isotherm measurements.

elements.content: Compounds 1, 2, and 3 were prepared and isolated from the one-pot self-assembly reaction of copper(II) perchlorate and tpbn in methanol solution, followed by the addition of aqueous methanolic solution of disodium salt of dicarboxylic acid under ambient conditions (Scheme ). All three products were obtained as precipitates, and thus the separation of byproduct, sodium perchlorate, was very easy, as it is soluble in both methanol and water, yielding pure products.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Compounds 1, 2, and 3 were prepared and isolated from the one-pot self-assembly reaction of copper(II) perchlorate and tpbn in methanol solution, followed by the addition of aqueous methanolic solution of disodium salt of dicarboxylic acid under ambient conditions (Scheme ). All three products were obtained as precipitates, and thus the separation of byproduct, sodium perchlorate, was very easy, as it is soluble in both methanol and water, yielding pure products.

elements.content: Based on the IR spectra of 1, 2, and 3 (Figures S1–S3 of the ) recorded in the solid state as KBr pellets, the asymmetric and symmetric stretching frequencies for the carboxylate group appear at 1595 and 1375 cm–1 (1), 1582 and 1304 cm–1 (2), and 1594 and 1381 cm–1 (3), respectively. The difference between the two stretching frequencies is indicative of the monodentate binding mode of the carboxylate; this is what is found in the crystal structures (vide infra). The peaks at 1101 and 624 cm–1 (1), 1110 and 620 cm–1 (2), and 1071 and 622 cm–1 (3) can be attributed to the anionic perchlorates present in it. Other peaks, with a shift of a few wavenumbers, are due to the ligand which is common in all.

elements.content:
Crystals of 1a, 2a, and 3a suitable for single-crystal X-ray studies were grown from the slow evaporation of their solution in a mixture of water and acetonitrile.

Structure of <bold>1a</bold>

1a is a molecular rectangle that crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbca space group. All Cu(II) centers are pentacoordinated, surrounded by three nitrogens of the ligand, one water molecule, and one monodentate carboxylate of the linker. Two Cu(II) centers are connected by the glutarate in one direction (e.g., along x-axis) and by the ligand in the other direction (e.g., along the y-axis), forming a molecular rectangle with a dimension of 15.575 Å × 8.441 Å, as shown in Figure . Compound 1a is the first example of the use of an aliphatic dicarboxylate to make a molecular rectangle. Examples of Cu(II) complexes of malonate, succinate, and glutarate containing ancillary ligands reported prior to this work are structurally different from 1a. In the literature, many rigid dicarboxylates have been used to synthesize molecular rectangles of Cu(II), e.g., [(Cu2L)2­(terephthalate)2]­X4 (where X = triflate or perchlorate and L = hexaaza­cyclophane macrocyclic ligand) and [Cu4(L)4­(Py)8]·​2DMF·​10H2O (where H2L = 7-oxa­dibenzo­fluorene-3,11-dicarboxylic acid). Other examples of molecular rectangles of Cu(II) are known with the neutral ligands, like bis(phenyl(2-pyridyl)­methanone)­thiocarbazone in [Cu2Cl2L]2 and [Cu4L4­{μ-1,5-(NCNCN)2}] (ClO4)2­(H2O)2·2H2O (where L = {2-((2-dimethylamino-ethylamino)­methyl)phenol).
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Structure Description

Crystals of 1a, 2a, and 3a suitable for single-crystal X-ray studies were grown from the slow evaporation of their solution in a mixture of water and acetonitrile.

Structure of 1a 

 1a is a molecular rectangle that crystallizes in the orthorhombic Pbca space group. All Cu(II) centers are pentacoordinated, surrounded by three nitrogens of the ligand, one water molecule, and one monodentate carboxylate of the linker. Two Cu(II) centers are connected by the glutarate in one direction (e.g., along x-axis) and by the ligand in the other direction (e.g., along the y-axis), forming a molecular rectangle with a dimension of 15.575 Å × 8.441 Å, as shown in Figure . Compound 1a is the first example of the use of an aliphatic dicarboxylate to make a molecular rectangle. Examples of Cu(II) complexes of malonate, succinate, and glutarate containing ancillary ligands reported prior to this work are structurally different from 1a. In the literature, many rigid dicarboxylates have been used to synthesize molecular rectangles of Cu(II), e.g., [(Cu2L)2(terephthalate)2]X4 (where X = triflate or perchlorate and L = hexaazacyclophane macrocyclic ligand) and [Cu4(L)4(Py)8]⋅2DMF⋅10H2O (where H2L = 7-oxadibenzofluorene-3,11-dicarboxylic acid). Other examples of molecular rectangles of Cu(II) are known with the neutral ligands, like bis(phenyl(2-pyridyl)methanone)thiocarbazone in [Cu2Cl2L]2 and [Cu4L4{μ-1,5-(NCNCN)2}] (ClO4)2(H2O)2⋅2H2O (where L = {2-((2-dimethylamino-ethylamino)methyl)phenol).

elements.content: Structure of molecular rectangle 1a.
elements.clean_text: 3  Structure of molecular rectangle 1a.

elements.content: In 1a, the glutarate binds in a bis(monodentate) syn–anti fashion to the Cu(II) centers. The methylene chain of glutarate can adopt three orientations: gauche–gauche, gauche–anti, and anti–anti. In compound 1a, the torsional angles around the methylene chain of glutarate are 177.07° and 173.28°, which suggests that the glutarate is in an anti–anti orientation. The Cu(II)···Cu(II) distances are 7.964 Å (connected by tpbn) and 9.669 Å (connected by glutarate). The direction of the coordinated water molecules on the Cu(II) centers is found to be different: out of four water molecules, two are found to be pointing inside the cavity and the other two point outside the cavity. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1 of the .
elements.clean_text: In 1a, the glutarate binds in a bis(monodentate) syn-anti fashion to the Cu(II) centers. The methylene chain of glutarate can adopt three orientations: gauche-gauche, gauche-anti, and anti-anti. In compound 1a, the torsional angles around the methylene chain of glutarate are 177.07° and 173.28°, which suggests that the glutarate is in an anti-anti orientation. The Cu(II)⋅⋅⋅Cu(II) distances are 7.964 Å (connected by tpbn) and 9.669 Å (connected by glutarate). The direction of the coordinated water molecules on the Cu(II) centers is found to be different: out of four water molecules, two are found to be pointing inside the cavity and the other two point outside the cavity. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1 of the .

elements.content: The lattice water molecules are found to be inside the cavity of the rectangle. These water molecules are hydrogen-bonded among themselves, with the coordinated water molecules (those pointing inside the cavity) and uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the carboxylate forming a hexagonal motif (R6 6(6)), as shown by blue lines in Figure .
elements.clean_text: The lattice water molecules are found to be inside the cavity of the rectangle. These water molecules are hydrogen-bonded among themselves, with the coordinated water molecules (those pointing inside the cavity) and uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the carboxylate forming a hexagonal motif (R6 6(6)), as shown by blue lines in Figure .

elements.content: Association of molecular rectangles via hydrogen-bonding in 1a.
elements.clean_text: 4  Association of molecular rectangles via hydrogen-bonding in 1a.

elements.content: Two such molecular rectangles are connected with each other via two perchlorate anions which are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water molecules (pointing outside the cavity) of these rectangles in one direction. The perchlorate anions connecting the two molecular rectangles also form an 8-membered motif, R6 6(8). Further, these perchlorate anions are hydrogen-bonded to another molecular rectangle in two directions, forming a chair-shaped supramolecular assembly (see Figure ). All the hydrogen-bonding parameters are listed in Table . Furthermore, these rectangles are connected via π–π interactions in two planes (centroid–centroid distances: 3.632 and 3.803 Å), as shown in Figure S4 of the .
elements.clean_text: Two such molecular rectangles are connected with each other via two perchlorate anions which are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water molecules (pointing outside the cavity) of these rectangles in one direction. The perchlorate anions connecting the two molecular rectangles also form an 8-membered motif, R6 6(8). Further, these perchlorate anions are hydrogen-bonded to another molecular rectangle in two directions, forming a chair-shaped supramolecular assembly (see Figure ). All the hydrogen-bonding parameters are listed in Table . Furthermore, these rectangles are connected via π-π interactions in two planes (centroid-centroid distances: 3.632 and 3.803 Å), as shown in Figure S4 of the .

A helical 1D CP of 2a crystallizes in the monoclinic P21 chiral space group. A subtle change in the spacer atom in the dicarboxylate from CH2 of glutarate (vide supra) to O of diglyconate gave a totally different product. None of the components in 2a is chiral in nature; its chirality is due to the orientation of the diglyconate linker. As depicted in Figure , the open sites in the dimetal subunit {Cu2(tpbn)}4+ are such that the binding of the diglyconate provides a step-style CP. In this case, both copper centers are pentacoordinated, but the coordination environment around Cu(II) centers is different. One of the Cu(II) centers is surrounded by three nitrogens of the ligand, one water molecule, and one oxygen atom of the carboxylate; the second Cu(II) center has a coordinated perchlorate instead of water (see Figure ). The diglyconate binds in a bis(monodentate) syn–syn fashion, which is different from the glutarate binding in 1a. The Cu(II)···Cu(II) distances are 6.91 Å (connected by tpbn) and 10.023 Å (connected by diglyconate). Only mononuclear Cu(II) and Ni(II) complexes of diglyconate (abbreviated as oda) with bidentate pyridyl ligands, such as 1,10-phenanthroline, are reported.

Structure of 2a 

A helical 1D CP of 2a crystallizes in the monoclinic P21 chiral space group. A subtle change in the spacer atom in the dicarboxylate from CH2 of glutarate (vide supra) to O of diglyconate gave a totally different product. None of the components in 2a is chiral in nature; its chirality is due to the orientation of the diglyconate linker. As depicted in Figure , the open sites in the dimetal subunit {Cu2(tpbn)}4+ are such that the binding of the diglyconate provides a step-style CP. In this case, both copper centers are pentacoordinated, but the coordination environment around Cu(II) centers is different. One of the Cu(II) centers is surrounded by three nitrogens of the ligand, one water molecule, and one oxygen atom of the carboxylate; the second Cu(II) center has a coordinated perchlorate instead of water (see Figure ). The diglyconate binds in a bis(monodentate) syn-syn fashion, which is different from the glutarate binding in 1a. The Cu(II)⋅⋅⋅Cu(II) distances are 6.91 Å (connected by tpbn) and 10.023 Å (connected by diglyconate). Only mononuclear Cu(II) and Ni(II) complexes of diglyconate (abbreviated as oda) with bidentate pyridyl ligands, such as 1,10-phenanthroline, are reported.

elements.content: On the other hand, without any ancillary ligand, there are several metal–diglyconate complexes, such as [Mn(H2O)­(oda)­(H2O)2] n , that have polymeric structures. Most of these complexes have an M–Oether bond, but in compound 2a there is no such bond. In 2a, the Cu–Ocarb distances are 1.931 and 1.984 Å, showing a narrow range compared to those in other complexes reported in the literature, which vary from 1.937(3) to 2.862(5) Å. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1 of the .

In 2a, the Cu-Ocarb distances are 1.931 and 1.984 Å, showing a narrow range compared to those in other complexes reported in the literature, which vary from 1.937(3) to 2.862(5) Å. The selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table S1 of the .

elements.content: The coordinated water on one of the copper centers is intramolecularly hydrogen-bonded to the uncoordinated O atom of the carboxylate and the O atom of the coordinated carboxylate, forming two 5-membered rings sharing a common side (see Figure ). The hydrogen-bonding parameters are listed in Table . Furthermore, these rectangles are connected via π–π interactions in two planes (centroid–centroid distances: 3.786 and 3.870 Å), as shown in Figure S5 of the .

elements.content: 3a is a molecular rectangle, similar to 1a, as shown in Figure . The pore size is 15.756 Å × 8.662 Å. The dicarboxylate 2,2′-thiodiacetate binds to the Cu(II) center in a similar fashion to that of glutarate in 1a. The Cu(II)···Cu(II) distances are 7.943 Å (connected by tpbn) and 9.918 Å (connected by 2,2′-thiodiacetate). These rectangles are connected via moderate π–π interactions in two planes (centroid–centroid distances: 3.617 and 3.836 Å), as shown in Figure S6 of the . While many polymeric networks of transition elements, such as Co(II), Cu(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II), with 2,2′-thiodiacetate are reported in the literature, a few examples of mononuclear complexes are also reported with a bidentate nitrogen-based linker, such as 1,10-phenanthroline. In most of these complexes a metal–S bond is found, whereas no such bond is present in 3a. The Cu(II)–Ocarb distances in 3a are 1.946 and 2.035 Å, which are much shorter than those reported in the literature. To the best of our knowledge, there is no molecular rectangle reported in the literature with 2,2′-thiodiacetate. Inside the cavity of the rectangles of 3a, the lattice water molecules are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water molecules pointing inside the cavity to form a hexameric motif within the rectangle (shown by pink lines in Figure ). This hexameric motif is hydrogen-bonded to the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the 2,2′-thiodiacetate. The molecular rectangles are connected with each other through coordinated water molecules (those pointing outside the cavity) via perchlorate anions. Due to the hydrogen-bonding, two channels of perchlorate anions are formed, labeled as 1 and 2 in Figure .

Structure of 3a 

 3a is a molecular rectangle, similar to 1a, as shown in Figure . The pore size is 15.756 Å × 8.662 Å. The dicarboxylate 2,2'-thiodiacetate binds to the Cu(II) center in a similar fashion to that of glutarate in 1a. The Cu(II)⋅⋅⋅Cu(II) distances are 7.943 Å (connected by tpbn) and 9.918 Å (connected by 2,2'-thiodiacetate). These rectangles are connected via moderate π-π interactions in two planes (centroid-centroid distances: 3.617 and 3.836 Å), as shown in Figure S6 of the . While many polymeric networks of transition elements, such as Co(II), Cu(II), Ni(II), and Zn(II), with 2,2'-thiodiacetate are reported in the literature, a few examples of mononuclear complexes are also reported with a bidentate nitrogen-based linker, such as 1,10-phenanthroline. In most of these complexes a metal-S bond is found, whereas no such bond is present in 3a. The Cu(II)-Ocarb distances in 3a are 1.946 and 2.035 Å, which are much shorter than those reported in the literature. To the best of our knowledge, there is no molecular rectangle reported in the literature with 2,2'-thiodiacetate. Inside the cavity of the rectangles of 3a, the lattice water molecules are hydrogen-bonded to the coordinated water molecules pointing inside the cavity to form a hexameric motif within the rectangle (shown by pink lines in Figure ). This hexameric motif is hydrogen-bonded to the uncoordinated oxygen atoms of the 2,2'-thiodiacetate. The molecular rectangles are connected with each other through coordinated water molecules (those pointing outside the cavity) via perchlorate anions. Due to the hydrogen-bonding, two channels of perchlorate anions are formed, labeled as 1 and 2 in Figure .

elements.content: In this study, three dicarboxylates differing in the spacer atom are used to explore whether that has any effect on the formation of products. With subtle changes in the spacer atoms of the dicarboxylates, diverse products are formed. The dicarboxylates with CH2 and S as spacer atoms result in the formation of a molecular rectangle, whereas a helical 1D CP was obtained with a dicarboxylate having O as a spacer atom. The important difference in these dicarboxylic acids is the electronegativity of the spacer atom: oxygen is more electronegative than carbon and sulfur, both of which have almost the same electronegativity (C, 2.55; S, 2.58). On the other hand, the angles around the spacer atoms (flexibility) observed in 1a–3a are 110.21°, 111.06°, and 97.17°, respectively. Other factors that can be responsible for the formation of these products are steric hindrance and crystal packing (see Figures S7–S9 of the ). Considering all these possibilities, one can link the difference in electronegativity for 1 and 2, while the flexibility can be the reason for 2 and 3. Although the O atom in diglyconate is not involved in coordination with Cu(II), unlike other examples of this ligands (vide supra), its participation in strong hydrogen-bonding with the coordinated water molecule in tandem with the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms forming the edge-shared two 5-membered motifs in 2 is definitely a striking difference compared to the other two carboxylates (glutarate and 2,2′-thiodiacetate), which are not expected to bond in such a way.

elements.content: To confirm whether the single-crystal structure corresponds to the bulk material, powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded for 1–3 at room temperature. The experimental and simulated (from the single-crystal data) patterns were similar to each other (see Figures S10–S12 of the ). The patterns obtained confirm that the single-crystal and bulk material are the same. It also confirms the phase purity of the bulk sample.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Data Analysis

To confirm whether the single-crystal structure corresponds to the bulk material, powder X-ray diffraction patterns were recorded for 1-3 at room temperature. The experimental and simulated (from the single-crystal data) patterns were similar to each other (see Figures S10-S12 of the ). The patterns obtained confirm that the single-crystal and bulk material are the same. It also confirms the phase purity of the bulk sample.

elements.content: All three compounds have been investigated by ESI mass spectrometry and UV–vis spectroscopy to compare their structures in the solution state. In order to remove any doubt that the solid-state structures are intact in solution, their mass spectral data have been very useful. The peaks observed for consecutive loss of perchlorate anions from each compound are summarized in Table . These values confirm that the molecules do not lose their identity in the solution state.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Studies of 1-3 

All three compounds have been investigated by ESI mass spectrometry and UV-vis spectroscopy to compare their structures in the solution state. In order to remove any doubt that the solid-state structures are intact in solution, their mass spectral data have been very useful. The peaks observed for consecutive loss of perchlorate anions from each compound are summarized in Table . These values confirm that the molecules do not lose their identity in the solution state.

Furthermore, the UV–vis spectra for 1, 2, and 3 show peaks at 644, 637, and 674 nm, respectively, due to d-d transitions (2Eg to 2T2g) of the copper(II) center (Figure ). The difference in these values provides information about the electronic and structural environment around the Cu(II) centers. The λmax values for 1 and 3 are close to each other, which is also in good agreement with their solid-state structures; structurally 1 and 3 are similar, except that CH2 in 1 is replaced by S in 3. On the other hand, 2 shows a red shift compared to 1 and 3.

elements.content: Additionally, the chirality of 2 was verified in the solution state by polarimetry. The negative value (−40.0) of the specific rotation in 0.1 mM aqueous solution shows that it is a left-handed helical structure.

elements.content: In order to establish a structure–​property correlation, water vapor adsorption studies were carried out for 1–3. Each sample was pre-treated for 16 h at 100 °C under vacuum, followed by purging with nitrogen. As can be seen from Figure , the maximum of water vapor (125 cm3 per g of 1; 10.5 water molecules per molecule of 1) adsorbed by 1 is less than the amount of water vapor retained on desorption by 3 (135 cm3 per g of 3; 11.7 water molecules per molecule of 3). At p/p o = 1 (where p o is the vapor pressure at saturation), 3 adsorbed approximately 190 cm3 water vapor per gram of sample (16 water molecules per molecule of 3) in a stepwise fashion. This value indicates a strong adsorbate–​adsorbate interaction via hydrogen-bonding at higher p/p o. At lower p/p o = 0.2, 3 adsorbs 90 cm3 water vapor per gram of sample (7.6 water molecules per molecule of 3); interestingly, the same value is observed for 1 on desorption. In both cases, the desorption curve does not follow the adsorption one, generating a prominent hysteresis profile that is indicative of hydrophilic nature of the pore surfaces in them. However, the hysteresis of 1 shows more area than that of 3. Both can be good candidates for desiccant application. 2 shows the least affinity toward water, which correlates well with its 1D polymeric structure. This study further indicates how the structures of 1–3 are related to their affinity toward water.

elements.content: For the greenhouse effect, which is one of the major concerns today, sequestering carbon dioxide has become a very important subject to study. Various groups around the world are engaged in such studies using porous materials. Out of the three compounds in our study, both of the molecular rectangles were studied for adsoprtion of carbon dioxide (see Figure S13 of the ). Molecular rectangle 1 showed maximum adsorption at 16 cm3/g, whereas molecular rectangle 3 showed maximum adsorption at 5 cm3/g. On desorption, 1 retains 7 cm3/g, whereas 3 retains only 2 cm3/g. Although these rectangles showed very little adsorption of carbon dioxide, this provides impetus for further work focused on increasing the length of ligands and linkers, which will increase the pore sizes in these molecular rectangles. It should also be noted that no significant adsorption of dinitrogen (not shown) by these rectangles was observed, making these selective for carbon dioxide only.

elements.clean_text:
EPR and Magnetic Properties

The X-band EPR spectra of 1-3 (Figures S14-S16 of the ) at 77 K show a broad isotropic signal centered at g = 2, characteristics of square-pyramidal geometry and (d x 2  -y 2 )1 ground-state electronic configurations for the Cu(II) ions. Analogous spectra have been observed for other weakly magnetically (vide infra) coupled complexes with syn-anti and syn-syn carboxylate bridges.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility data were recorded for 1–3 from 300 to 2 K. Plots of χT versus T for 1–3 are shown in Figure , while plots of 1/χ versus T are shown in Figures S17–S19 of the . The χT values at 300 K for 1–3 are very similar to each other: 0.385 cm3 K/mol Cu for 1, 0.418 cm3 K/mol Cu for 2, and 0.42 cm3 K/mol Cu for 3. In all complexes, there are two kinds of Cu(II)···Cu(II) distances: one connected by the tpbn ligand, and the other connected by the dicarboxylate. Thus, most likely the magnetic interactions between Cu(II) ions linked by the tpbn ligand will be ferromagnetic, and the interactions between Cu(II) ions linked by the carboxylate could be antiferromagnetic, with the antiferromagnetic interactions being relatively stronger in the molecular rectangles, as evidenced by the net antiferromagnetic Weiss temperature.

elements.content: For 1, the χT is weakly temperature dependent and decreases monotonically down to low temperatures, suggesting antiferromagnetic interactions between the Cu(II) centers with S = 1/2 moments. A fit of the high-temperature data with the Curie–Weiss expression, χ = χ 0 + C T − θ where C is the Curie constant and θ is the Weiss temperature, gave the following values for the parameters: χ0 = 2.3 × 10–4 cm3/mol Cu, C = 0.41 cm3 K/mol Cu, and θ = −11 K. While the value obtained for C is close to the value expected for effective S = 1/2 moments with g = 2, the small and negative value of θ indicates that these Cu(II) centers with S = 1/2 moments interact weakly with each other antiferromagnetically. The corresponding values for 2 are χ0 = −3.43 × 10–5 cm3/mol Cu, C = 0.42 cm3 K/mol Cu, and θ = +7.5 K, with g = 2.05. In the case of 2, the small and positive value of θ indicates that these S = 1/2 moments couple very weakly but ferromagnetically. For 3, the χT value is constant for the temperature range 200–300 K and decreases for lower temperatures down to about 50 K, suggesting that there are weak antiferromagnetic interactions between Cu(II) ions. The following values of the parameters are obtained for 3: χ0 = 2.3 × 10–5 cm3/mol Cu, C = 0.42 cm3 K/mol Cu, and θ = −6.4 K, with g = 2.05. Below 25 K, the χT value increases abruptly and reaches a maximum of 0.48 cm3 K/mol Cu before decreasing again for lower temperatures. The abrupt increase strongly suggests that there are weak ferromagnetic interactions present which increase the effective moment per Cu at these temperatures. The exchange interactions observed in 1–3 are comparable to those in similar systems reported in the literature.

elements.content: The magnetization (M) versus field (H) data measured at 2 K for 1–3 are shown in Figure . The M(H) curves were measured with increasing and decreasing field between H = 0 and 8.75 T. For all three compounds, no hysteresis was observed between increasing and decreasing field measurements, indicating the absence of any ferro- or ferrimagnetic component to the magnetism. The saturation values M s observed for 1–3 (≈ 0.88, 1.02, and 1.03 μB, respectively) are close to what one expects (M s = gS z ≈ 1 μB) for an effective S = 1/2 moment. For 1, the overall behavior of M as a function of H is similar to what is expected for free or weakly interacting paramagnetic moments. The magnetization increases mono­tonically and saturates at the highest field. For 2, the behavior of M as a function of H is a typical Brillouin function, like the behavior expected for free or weakly interacting paramagnetic moments. The magnetization increases monotonically and saturates at the highest field. For 3, the magnetization increases monotonically and saturates at the highest field. At very low fields (H ≤ 100 G), an abrupt increase in M is observed, after which M increases roughly linearly with H. The abrupt increase at low fields is most likely due to a tiny amount of ferromagnetic impurity in the material which saturates already at H = 100 G.

elements.content: In this article we have demonstrated the effect of a spacer atom on the formation of diverse metal–organic coordination networks. Molecular rectangles were obtained with CH2 and S as spacer atoms, whereas a 1D helical coordination polymer was obtained with O as a spacer atom in the dicarboxylate linker. Important differences in these dicarboxylic acids are the electronegativity of the spacer atom and the angle around the spacer atoms (flexibility) observed in 1a–3a (110.21°, 111.06°, and 97.17°, respectively). One can link the difference in electronegativity to the difference in the structures for 1 and 2, while the flexibility can be the reason for the different structures for 2 and 3. Although the O atom in diglyconate is not involved in coordination with Cu(II), its participation in strong hydrogen-bonding with the coordinated water molecule, in tandem with the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms forming the edge-shared two 5-membered motifs in 2, is definitely a striking difference compared to the other two carboxylates (glutarate and 2,2′-thiodiacetate), which are not expected to bond such a way. Their stability in the solution state, determined by mass spectrometry, indicates that the solid-state structures are intact in solution. Their water vapor and gas (carbon dioxide and nitrogen) adsorption properties correlate well with the solid-state structures. Based on the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements between 2 and 300 K, a magneto-structural correlation was established where the rectangles showed weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Cu(II) centers, while weak ferromagnetic interactions wee observed between the Cu(II) centers in the CP. Further work to increase the pore size of these rectangles is in progress in our laboratory.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this article we have demonstrated the effect of a spacer atom on the formation of diverse metal-organic coordination networks. Molecular rectangles were obtained with CH2 and S as spacer atoms, whereas a 1D helical coordination polymer was obtained with O as a spacer atom in the dicarboxylate linker. Important differences in these dicarboxylic acids are the electronegativity of the spacer atom and the angle around the spacer atoms (flexibility) observed in 1a-3a (110.21°, 111.06°, and 97.17°, respectively). One can link the difference in electronegativity to the difference in the structures for 1 and 2, while the flexibility can be the reason for the different structures for 2 and 3. Although the O atom in diglyconate is not involved in coordination with Cu(II), its participation in strong hydrogen-bonding with the coordinated water molecule, in tandem with the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms forming the edge-shared two 5-membered motifs in 2, is definitely a striking difference compared to the other two carboxylates (glutarate and 2,2'-thiodiacetate), which are not expected to bond such a way. Their stability in the solution state, determined by mass spectrometry, indicates that the solid-state structures are intact in solution. Their water vapor and gas (carbon dioxide and nitrogen) adsorption properties correlate well with the solid-state structures. Based on the variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility measurements between 2 and 300 K, a magneto-structural correlation was established where the rectangles showed weak antiferromagnetic interactions between the Cu(II) centers, while weak ferromagnetic interactions wee observed between the Cu(II) centers in the CP. Further work to increase the pore size of these rectangles is in progress in our laboratory.

First, 46.5 mg (0.125 mmol) of Cu(ClO4)2·​6H2O and 28.5 mg (0.0625 mmol) of tpbn were dissolved in 3 mL of methanol.
